awd_titl_txt: Building a Grades K-2 Early Algebra Learning Progression Prototype for Diverse Populations
awd_abstract_narration:
Research indicates that students need sustained algebra instruction throughout Grades K-12 mathematics education, if their informal intuitions about mathematical structure and relationships are to be transformed into the more formal ways of mathematical thinking. Currently, however, no research-based models are available to guide the development, characterization, and assessment of young children's algebraic thinking, particularly at the start of formal schooling. This study will design a curricular framework for developing children's algebraic thinking across Grades K-2, with a particular focus on understanding how to support the teaching and learning of algebra with students in at-risk settings. Study outcomes will include a prototype Grades K-2 instructional sequence, related assessments, and characterizations of progressions in students' thinking as they advance through the instructional sequence. The impact of this work would be to provide a critical roadmap for teaching and learning algebra in Grades K-2 that can clarify and deepen the role of algebra in the elementary grades, strengthen current college and career readiness standards and practices, and provide curricular support for elementary teachers in systematically developing children's algebraic thinking.

The study will use design research to develop and empirically test a K-2 Early Algebra Learning Progression prototype for diverse learners. The context for this study is a North Carolina elementary school, which consists of a student population that is 64% non-white, with 63% categorized as low SES and 27% as English Language Learners. The sample consists of approximately 60 Grades K-2 students. To empirically test the prototype's framework, learning goals, and instructional sequence, classroom teaching experiments (CTEs) will be conducted in conjunction with individual student interviews. These interviews will be conducted at three time points (pre, mid, and post) during the CTEs. Qualitative methods of analysis will be used to identify themes regarding children's understanding of core algebraic thinking practices and concepts in CTE and interview data. Quantitative methods will also be used to identify patterns of growth in students' algebraic thinking from interview data. Results will be used to refine the framework, goals, and sequence, as well as to identify levels of sophistication in children's thinking as they advance through the sequence. Interview assessments conducted during the CTEs will be analyzed for psychometric soundness to ensure they are valid and reliable. In particular, inter-rater reliability measures will be used to ensure that coding of interview data is consistent, internal consistency estimates of reliability will be calculated and used to remove or modify items, and stability of the assessment items will be examined through within-subject correlations of common items and used to remove or modify items. For validity, observed item difficulty will be correlated with predicted item difficulty by the project's expert advisory board to identify items that need modification or deletion.

The Discovery Research K-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools (RMTs). Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects.

por.por_cntn:
Teaching and learning algebra continue to be a focus of educational reform given algebra's role as a gatekeeper to students' access to STEM-related disciplines. National college and career readiness standards such as the Common Core State Standards for Mathematics provide important benchmarks for algebra learning beginning in kindergarten, and algebra education in secondary grades is generally well defined by existing mathematics curricula. However, innovative models for early algebra instruction in the elementary grades that provide a curricular roadmap for how algebra standards might be addressed for young learners are greatly needed. Building on a previously developed Grades 3-5 early algebra intervention that was shown to significantly increase children's algebra readiness for middle grades, this project developed a companion Grades K-2 early algebra intervention prototype that, when combined with the Grades 3-5 intervention, results in a research-based model for early algebra instruction across elementary grades.

The Grades K-2 intervention developed in this project was designed as a practical curricular resource that can support all learners, including students from low socioeconomic communities, students from underserved racial minority communities, English language learners, and students with learning differences. Like the Grades 3-5 intervention, the Grades K-2 intervention ("curriculum") is now commercially available and is packaged in affordable, grade-level, teacher-friendly books to ensure wider adoption in schools. It consists of about twenty 40-minute lessons for each grade that can be taught by classroom teachers as part of their regular mathematics instruction, as well as grade-level assessments to measure students' learning from the intervention. It was designed around a conceptual approach to algebraic thinking that focuses on the systematic development of young learners' ability to generalize, represent, justify, and reason with mathematical structure and relationships. It uses a spiraled approach in its treatment of content by which these core practices are continually addressed in each grade using increasingly sophisticated concepts, representations, and ways of thinking. Students' understanding is developed through hands-on investigations that use concrete and visual tools and that engage learners in rich mathematical conversations. Initial design studies show the intervention?s potential for developing students' understanding of the algebraic concepts addressed in the intervention. Moreover, the use of concrete and visual tools embedded in lessons to support learning helps students make sense of important early algebraic concepts such as equations, the equal sign, and structure and relationships in arithmetic.

The Grades K-2 early algebra intervention developed in this project can serve as a critical instructional resource for teachers that can open pathways of success for all students in algebra, with the potential to broaden the participation of underserved communities in the STEM pipeline by increasing their success in algebra.
